thread.section_title: Asia Business, Finance & Political News - The Wall Street Journal
thread.title: Test Your Smarts on Rates, China and ETF Mayhem
thread.title_full: Test Your Smarts on Rates, China and ETF Mayhem - WSJ

author: Victor Reklaitis
title: Test Your Smarts on Rates, China and ETF Mayhem
text:
0 COMMENTS The market didn’t find much relief in September, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 7.6% for the month after losing 6.6% in August. Last month’s most anticipated financial event—a Federal Reserve announcement on Sept. 17—weighed on stocks, as investors appeared to view the Fed’s decision to stand pat on interest rates as a sign that the central bank remains worried about the economy.
During September’s selling, shares in Chinese companies, car makers and miners were hard hit in particular. Meanwhile, the largest company by market value made waves with its latest iMustHaves.
How much do you know about last month’s news in fund investing and markets? Here’s a quiz to test your knowledge.
1. The Fed yet again made no change to interest rates. When did it last raise rates?
A. March 2000
B. June 2006
C. October 2008
D. September 2011
ANSWER: B. The U.S. central bank last raised rates nearly a decade ago. It then cut rates as the latest recession set in, setting its benchmark rate in December 2008 at 0% to 0.25%, where it has stayed.
Journal Report Insights from The Experts Read more at WSJ.com/WealthReport More in Investing in Funds & ETFs The 4 Things to Do Before Retirement Guide to the New Fund Rules Tough Year for Target-Date Funds ‘529’ Mismatch? Our College Q&A U.S.-Stock Funds Fall 8.2% in Quarter 2. Fill in the blank: A Wall Street Journal article said the Fed’s decision reflects in part Chairwoman Janet Yellen’s cautious nature, noting she likes to arrive at ____ hours early.
A. Fed meetings
B. parties
C. airports
D. the dentist
Answer: C. Ms. Yellen is known inside the central bank for liking to get to airports hours before departure and preparing weeks in advance for big speeches—reflections of a desire to avoid surprises, the Journal article said. Raising rates at a time of uncertainty about the economic outlook would have been out of character.
3. Analysts said funds backed by Beijing plowed money into slumping Chinese stocks in an effort to cheer up domestic investors before what September event?
A. A two-day holiday for Mao’s birthday
B. A two-day holiday for a parade commemorating World War II’s end
C. A one-day holiday in honor of basketball star Yao Ming’s birthday
D. A visit by Chinese President Xi Jinping to the New York Stock Exchange
Answer: B. The buying was ahead of a military parade to celebrate the 70th anniversary of World War II’s end. But traders managed to “rain on Beijing’s victory parade,” said a Journal headline, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling on Sept. 2 before markets closed for the hoopla.
4. China bear James Chanos has notched gains as Chinese stocks slide. How have his firm’s assets changed lately?
A. His firm manages $6 billion, down from $10 billion in 2009.
B. His firm manages $3.4 billion, up from $2.5 billion earlier this year.
C. Assets under management have held steady at $4 billion for five years.
D. His firm manages $20 billion after attracting $1 billion a year for a decade.
Answer: B. Mr. Chanos, a short seller who runs hedge fund Kynikos Associates LP, saw his firm’s assets under management rise to $3.4 billion from $2.5 billion earlier this year. His firm, named after the Greek word for cynic, had managed about $6 billion in 2010, but then 2012 and 2013 were especially rough for short sellers.
5. Fill in the blank: Mark Wiedman, global head of BlackRock Inc. BLK 2.51 % ’s iShares unit, defended how an iShares ETF performed during recent market turmoil, saying it only “had ____ where it didn’t function properly.”
A. Two stock exchanges
B. Two days in September
C. 303 seconds
D. An imperceptible hiccup
Answer: C. “The fund has been out there trading great for 12 years,” said Mr. Wiedman, according to a Journal article on Sept. 13 about wild August trading that exposed flaws in exchange-traded funds. “It had 303 seconds where it didn’t function properly, where it was pricing bizarrely. You have to keep it in perspective.”
6. A Hillary Clinton tweet on Sept. 21 rattled investors in which sector?
A. Ride-sharing services
B. Social media
C, Sports fantasy-league websites
D. Biotechnology
Answer: D. Biotech stocks dived after the Democratic presidential candidate tweeted that she would lay out a plan to take on “price gouging” by specialty drug makers.
7. Volkswagen AG VLKAY -2.74 % ’s CEO resigned over the German car maker’s emissions scandal. What is that ex-leader’s name?
A. Martin Winterkorn
B. Peter Sommerkartoffel
C. Ferdinand Piech
D. Wolfgang Porsche
Answer: A. Mr. Winterkorn stepped down on Sept. 23 after VW’s shares had double-digit percentage losses in two days, as other auto-industry stocks also dropped. He said he would “accept responsibility” and the company “needs a fresh start.”
8. Apple Inc. AAPL 0.73 % unveiled new iPhones, iPads and the Apple Pencil. What did many analysts view as the biggest news?
A. Apple’s new $32-a-month plan to lease iPhones and offer annual upgrades
B. Apple’s Hermès watch costing $1,100 to $1,500
C. Apple TV supporting third-party developer apps for the first time
D. Apple’s hints that its next iPad Pro will have a 30-inch screen
Answer: A. The biggest development had to do with how a lot of iPhone fans could end up paying for their handsets, according to many analysts. Under the new iPhone upgrade program, customers can pay $32 a month for a 16-gigabyte iPhone 6S and upgrade to a new device after making 12 payments. A Barron’s article said Apple’s stock “could soar 50% in the coming year” thanks in part to the leasing program, which “attacks the primary bear case on Apple—slowing iPhone growth.”
9. Mining-company stocks struggled in New York and London amid worries about China’s economic slowdown. What price did Switzerland’s Glencore GLNCY 11.88 % PLC slip under for the first time on Sept. 22?
A. £100
B. £10
C. £5
D. £1
Answer: D. It fell briefly under £1 ($1.50).
10. In early September, ECB President Mario Draghi said its bond-buying program could “run until the end of
